Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: defaultCooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes before another scaling activity can start. The default value is 300. This cooldown period is not used when a scaling-specific cooldown is specified.

Cooldown periods are not supported for target tracking scaling policies, step scaling policies, or scheduled scaling. For more information, see Scaling Cooldowns in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group after this operation completes and the capacity it attempts to maintain.

This number must be greater than or equal to the minimum size of the group and less than or equal to the maximum size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: healthCheckGracePeriod
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits before checking the health status of an EC2 instance that has come into service. The default value is 0.

For more information, see Health Check Grace Period in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Conditional: This parameter is required if you are adding an ELB health check.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: healthCheckType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract: The service to use for the health checks. The valid values are EC2 and ELB. If you configure an Auto Scaling group to use ELB health checks, it considers the instance unhealthy if it fails either the EC2 status checks or the load balancer health checks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract: The name of the launch configuration. If you specify LaunchConfigurationName in your update request, you can’t specify LaunchTemplate or MixedInstancesPolicy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: launchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The launch template and version to use to specify the updates. If you specify LaunchTemplate in your update request, you can’t specify LaunchConfigurationName or MixedInstancesPolicy.

For more information, see LaunchTemplateSpecification in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: maxInstanceLifetime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The maximum amount of time, in seconds, that an instance can be in service. The default is null.

This parameter is optional, but if you specify a value for it, you must specify a value of at least 604,800 seconds (7 days). To clear a previously set value, specify a new value of 0.

For more information, see Replacing Auto Scaling Instances Based on Maximum Instance Lifetime in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 0.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The maximum size of the Auto Scaling group.

With a mixed instances policy that uses instance weighting, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling may need to go above MaxSize to meet your capacity requirements. In this event, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will never go above MaxSize by more than your maximum instance weight (weights that define how many capacity units each instance contributes to the capacity of the group).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract: The minimum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: mixedInstancesPolicy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
An embedded object that specifies a mixed instances policy.

In your call to UpdateAutoScalingGroup, you can make changes to the policy that is specified. All optional parameters are left unchanged if not specified.

For more information, see MixedInstancesPolicy in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference and Auto Scaling Groups with Multiple Instance Types and Purchase Options in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: latestInstancesProtectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
Indicates whether newly launched instances are protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

For more information about preventing instances from terminating on scale in, see Instance Protection in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: placementGroup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract: The name of the placement group into which to launch your instances, if any. A placement group is a logical grouping of instances within a single Availability Zone. You cannot specify multiple Availability Zones and a placement group. For more information, see Placement Groups in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: serviceLinkedRoleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service-linked role that the Auto Scaling group uses to call other AWS services on your behalf. For more information, see Service-Linked Roles in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: terminationPolicies
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
A standalone termination policy or a list of termination policies used to select the instance to terminate. The policies are executed in the order that they are listed.

For more information, see Controlling Which Instances Auto Scaling Terminates During Scale In in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.name: VPCZoneIdentifier
Classes/AWSAutoScalingUpdateAutoScalingG.abstract:
A comma-separated list of subnet IDs for virtual private cloud (VPC).

If you specify VPCZoneIdentifier with AvailabilityZones, the subnets that you specify for this parameter must reside in those Availability Zones.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTerminateInstanceI.name: shouldDecrementDesiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTerminateInstanceI.abstract: Indicates whether terminating the instance also decrements the size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.name: customizedMetricSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.abstract: A customized metric. You must specify either a predefined metric or a customized metric.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.name: disableScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.abstract: Indicates whether scaling in by the target tracking scaling policy is disabled. If scaling in is disabled, the target tracking scaling policy doesn’t remove instances from the Auto Scaling group. Otherwise, the target tracking scaling policy can remove instances from the Auto Scaling group. The default is false.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.name: predefinedMetricSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.abstract: A predefined metric. You must specify either a predefined metric or a customized metric.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagsType.html#/c:o.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagsType.html#/c:o.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.name: propagateAtLaunch
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.abstract: Determines whether the tag is added to new instances as they are launched in the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.name: resourceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.abstract: The type of resource. The only supported value is auto-scaling-group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html#/c:objc(c.name: propagateAtLaunch
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Determines whether the tag is added to new instances as they are launched in the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html#/c:objc(c.name: resourceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: The type of resource. The only supported value is auto-scaling-group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSuspendedProcess.h.name: suspensionReason
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSuspendedProcess.h.abstract: The reason that the process was suspended.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.name: metricIntervalLowerBound
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.abstract: The lower bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. If the metric value is above the breach threshold, the lower bound is inclusive (the metric must be greater than or equal to the threshold plus the lower bound). Otherwise, it is exclusive (the metric must be greater than the threshold plus the lower bound). A null value indicates negative infinity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.name: metricIntervalUpperBound
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.abstract:
The upper bound for the difference between the alarm threshold and the CloudWatch metric. If the metric value is above the breach threshold, the upper bound is exclusive (the metric must be less than the threshold plus the upper bound). Otherwise, it is inclusive (the metric must be less than or equal to the threshold plus the upper bound). A null value indicates positive infinity.

The upper bound must be greater than the lower bound.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.name: scalingAdjustment
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.abstract: The amount by which to scale, based on the specified adjustment type. A positive value adds to the current capacity while a negative number removes from the current capacity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.name: preferences
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.abstract: Set of preferences associated with the instance refresh request.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.name: strategy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.abstract:
The strategy to use for the instance refresh. The only valid value is Rolling.

A rolling update is an update that is applied to all instances in an Auto Scaling group until all instances have been updated. A rolling update can fail due to failed health checks or if instances are on standby or are protected from scale-in. If the rolling update process fails, any instances that were already replaced are not rolled back to their previous configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.name: instanceRefreshId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStartInstanceRefre.abstract: A unique ID for tracking the progress of the request.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceProtect.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceProtect.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceProtect.name: protectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceProtect.abstract: Indicates whether the instance is protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceHealthQ.name: healthStatus
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceHealthQ.abstract: The health status of the instance. Set to Healthy to have the instance remain in service. Set to Unhealthy to have the instance be out of service. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling terminates and replaces the unhealthy instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceHealthQ.name: shouldRespectGracePeriod
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetInstanceHealthQ.abstract:
If the Auto Scaling group of the specified instance has a HealthCheckGracePeriod specified for the group, by default, this call respects the grace period. Set this to False, to have the call not respect the grace period associated with the group.

For more information about the health check grace period, see CreateAutoScalingGroup in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.abstract: The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group after this operation completes and the capacity it attempts to maintain.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.name: honorCooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSetDesiredCapacity.abstract: Indicates whether Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits for the cooldown period to complete before initiating a scaling activity to set your Auto Scaling group to its new capacity. By default, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling does not honor the cooldown period during manual scaling activities.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group after the scheduled action runs and the capacity it attempts to maintain.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The date and time for the recurring schedule to end. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling does not perform the action after this time.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The maximum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The minimum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: recurrence
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract:
The recurring schedule for the action, in Unix cron syntax format. This format consists of five fields separated by white spaces: [Minute] [Hour] [Day_of_Month] [Month_of_Year] [Day_of_Week]. The value must be in quotes (for example, "30 0 1 1,6,12 *"). For more information about this format, see Crontab.

When StartTime and EndTime are specified with Recurrence, they form the boundaries of when the recurring action starts and stops.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract:
The date and time for the action to start, in YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ format in UTC/GMT only and in quotes (for example, "2019-06-01T00:00:00Z").

If you specify Recurrence and StartTime, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action at this time, and then performs the action based on the specified recurrence.

If you try to schedule the action in the past, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling returns an error message.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group after the scheduled action runs and the capacity it attempts to maintain.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The date and time in UTC for the recurring schedule to end. For example, "2019-06-01T00:00:00Z".

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The maximum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The minimum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: recurrence
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract:
The recurring schedule for the action, in Unix cron syntax format.

When StartTime and EndTime are specified with Recurrence, they form the boundaries of when the recurring action starts and stops.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: scheduledActionARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the scheduled action.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract: The date and time in UTC for this action to start. For example, "2019-06-01T00:00:00Z".

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledActionsTy.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledActionsTy.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingProcessQuer.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingProcessQuer.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingProcessQuer.name: scalingProcesses
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingProcessQuer.abstract:
One or more of the following processes:

  • Launch

  • Terminate

  • AddToLoadBalancer

  • AlarmNotification

  • AZRebalance

  • HealthCheck

  • InstanceRefresh

  • ReplaceUnhealthy

  • ScheduledActions

If you omit this parameter, all processes are specified.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: adjustmentType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The adjustment type, which specifies how ScalingAdjustment is interpreted. The valid values are ChangeInCapacity, ExactCapacity, and PercentChangeInCapacity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: alarms
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The CloudWatch alarms related to the policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: cooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes before any further dynamic scaling activities can start.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: enabled
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: Indicates whether the policy is enabled (true) or disabled (false).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: estimatedInstanceWarmup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The estimated time, in seconds, until a newly launched instance can contribute to the CloudWatch metrics.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: metricAggregationType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The aggregation type for the CloudWatch metrics. The valid values are Minimum, Maximum, and Average.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: minAdjustmentMagnitude
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The minimum number of instances to scale. If the value of AdjustmentType is PercentChangeInCapacity, the scaling policy changes the DesiredCapacity of the Auto Scaling group by at least this many instances. Otherwise, the error is ValidationError.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: policyARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: policyType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The policy type. The valid values are SimpleScaling, StepScaling, and TargetTrackingScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: scalingAdjustment
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: The amount by which to scale, based on the specified adjustment type. A positive value adds to the current capacity while a negative number removes from the current capacity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.name: stepAdjustments
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScalingPolicy.html.abstract: A set of adjustments that enable you to scale based on the size of the alarm breach.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.name: instanceWarmup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.abstract:
The number of seconds until a newly launched instance is configured and ready to use. During this time, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling does not immediately move on to the next replacement. The default is to use the value specified for the health check grace period for the group.

Note: While warming up, a newly launched instance is not counted toward the aggregated metrics of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.name: minHealthyPercentage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.abstract: The amount of capacity in the Auto Scaling group that must remain healthy during an instance refresh to allow the operation to continue, as a percentage of the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group (rounded up to the nearest integer). The default is 90.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingRecordLifecycleAct.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingRecordLifecycleAct.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingRecordLifecycleAct.name: lifecycleActionToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingRecordLifecycleAct.abstract: A token that uniquely identifies a specific lifecycle action associated with an instance. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends this token to the notification target that you specified when you created the lifecycle hook.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract: The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group after the scheduled action runs and the capacity it attempts to maintain. It can scale beyond this capacity if you add more scaling conditions.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract: The date and time for the recurring schedule to end. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling does not perform the action after this time.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract: The maximum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract: The minimum size of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: recurrence
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract:
The recurring schedule for this action, in Unix cron syntax format. This format consists of five fields separated by white spaces: [Minute] [Hour] [Day_of_Month] [Month_of_Year] [Day_of_Week]. The value must be in quotes (for example, "30 0 1 1,6,12 *"). For more information about this format, see Crontab.

When StartTime and EndTime are specified with Recurrence, they form the boundaries of when the recurring action starts and stops.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScheduledUpdate.abstract:
The date and time for this action to start, in YYYY-MM-DDThh:mm:ssZ format in UTC/GMT only and in quotes (for example, "2019-06-01T00:00:00Z").

If you specify Recurrence and StartTime, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action at this time, and then performs the action based on the specified recurrence.

If you try to schedule your action in the past, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling returns an error message.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: adjustmentType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
Specifies whether the ScalingAdjustment parameter is an absolute number or a percentage of the current capacity. The valid values are ChangeInCapacity, ExactCapacity, and PercentChangeInCapacity.

Valid only if the policy type is StepScaling or SimpleScaling. For more information, see Scaling Adjustment Types in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: cooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes before any further dynamic scaling activities can start. If this parameter is not specified, the default cooldown period for the group applies.

Valid only if the policy type is SimpleScaling. For more information, see Scaling Cooldowns in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: enabled
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract: Indicates whether the scaling policy is enabled or disabled. The default is enabled. For more information, see Disabling a Scaling Policy for an Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: estimatedInstanceWarmup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The estimated time, in seconds, until a newly launched instance can contribute to the CloudWatch metrics. The default is to use the value specified for the default cooldown period for the group.

Valid only if the policy type is StepScaling or TargetTrackingScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: metricAggregationType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The aggregation type for the CloudWatch metrics. The valid values are Minimum, Maximum, and Average. If the aggregation type is null, the value is treated as Average.

Valid only if the policy type is StepScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: minAdjustmentMagnitude
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The minimum value to scale by when scaling by percentages. For example, suppose that you create a step scaling policy to scale out an Auto Scaling group by 25 percent and you specify a MinAdjustmentMagnitude of 2. If the group has 4 instances and the scaling policy is performed, 25 percent of 4 is 1. However, because you specified a MinAdjustmentMagnitude of 2, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling scales out the group by 2 instances.

Valid only if the policy type is StepScaling or SimpleScaling and the adjustment type is PercentChangeInCapacity. For more information, see Scaling Adjustment Types in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: policyType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract: The policy type. The valid values are SimpleScaling, StepScaling, and TargetTrackingScaling. If the policy type is null, the value is treated as SimpleScaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: scalingAdjustment
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
The amount by which a simple scaling policy scales the Auto Scaling group in response to an alarm breach. The adjustment is based on the value that you specified in the AdjustmentType parameter (either an absolute number or a percentage). A positive value adds to the current capacity and a negative value subtracts from the current capacity. For exact capacity, you must specify a positive value.

Conditional: If you specify SimpleScaling for the policy type, you must specify this parameter. (Not used with any other policy type.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: stepAdjustments
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
A set of adjustments that enable you to scale based on the size of the alarm breach.

Conditional: If you specify StepScaling for the policy type, you must specify this parameter. (Not used with any other policy type.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.name: targetTrackingConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutScalingPolicyTy.abstract:
A target tracking scaling policy. Includes support for predefined or customized metrics.

For more information, see TargetTrackingConfiguration in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

Conditional: If you specify TargetTrackingScaling for the policy type, you must specify this parameter. (Not used with any other policy type.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: notificationTypes
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The type of event that causes the notification to be sent. To query the notification types supported by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling, call the DescribeAutoScalingNotificationTypes API.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.name: topicARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutNotificationCon.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: Defines the action the Auto Scaling group should take when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs. This parameter can be either CONTINUE or ABANDON. The default value is ABANDON.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out. The range is from 30 to 7200 seconds. The default value is 3600 seconds (1 hour).

If the lifecycle hook times out, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action that you specified in the DefaultResult parameter. You can prevent the lifecycle hook from timing out by calling the RecordLifecycleActionHeartbeat API.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: lifecycleTransition
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The instance state to which you want to attach the lifecycle hook. The valid values are:

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATING

Conditional: This parameter is required for new lifecycle hooks, but optional when updating existing hooks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract: Additional information that you want to include any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The ARN of the notification target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses to notify you when an instance is in the transition state for the lifecycle hook. This target can be either an SQS queue or an SNS topic.

If you specify an empty string, this overrides the current ARN.

This operation uses the JSON format when sending notifications to an Amazon SQS queue, and an email key-value pair format when sending notifications to an Amazon SNS topic.

When you specify a notification target, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends it a test message. Test messages contain the following additional key-value pair: "Event": "autoscaling:TEST_NOTIFICATION".

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPutLifecycleHookTy.abstract:
The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target, for example, an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue.

Conditional: This parameter is required for new lifecycle hooks, but optional when updating existing hooks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.name: predefinedMetricType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.abstract:
The metric type. The following predefined metrics are available:

  • ASGAverageCPUUtilization - Average CPU utilization of the Auto Scaling group.

  • ASGAverageNetworkIn - Average number of bytes received on all network interfaces by the Auto Scaling group.

  • ASGAverageNetworkOut - Average number of bytes sent out on all network interfaces by the Auto Scaling group.

  • ALBRequestCountPerTarget - Number of requests completed per target in an Application Load Balancer target group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.name: resourceLabel
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.abstract:
Identifies the resource associated with the metric type. You can’t specify a resource label unless the metric type is ALBRequestCountPerTarget and there is a target group attached to the Auto Scaling group.

Elastic Load Balancing sends data about your load balancers to Amazon CloudWatch. CloudWatch collects the data and specifies the format to use to access the data. The format is app/load-balancer-name/load-balancer-id/targetgroup/target-group-name/target-group-id, where

  • app/load-balancer-name/load-balancer-id is the final portion of the load balancer ARN, and

  • targetgroup/target-group-name/target-group-id is the final portion of the target group ARN.

To find the ARN for an Application Load Balancer, use the DescribeLoadBalancers API operation. To find the ARN for the target group, use the DescribeTargetGroups API operation.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.name: alarms
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.abstract: The CloudWatch alarms created for the target tracking scaling policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.name: policyARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPolicyARNType.html.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPoliciesType.html#.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPoliciesType.html#.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.name: topicARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingNotificationConfig.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Amazon Simple Notification Service (Amazon SNS) topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.name: instancesDistribution
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.abstract:
The instances distribution to use.

If you leave this parameter unspecified, the value for each parameter in InstancesDistribution uses a default value.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.name: launchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.abstract:
The launch template and instance types (overrides).

This parameter must be specified when creating a mixed instances policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricGranularityT.name: granularity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMetricGranularityT.abstract: The granularity. The only valid value is 1Minute.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.name: loadBalancerTargetGroupARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the target group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.name: state
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.abstract:
The state of the target group.

  • Adding - The Auto Scaling instances are being registered with the target group.

  • Added - All Auto Scaling instances are registered with the target group.

  • InService - At least one Auto Scaling instance passed an ELB health check.

  • Removing - The Auto Scaling instances are being deregistered from the target group. If connection draining is enabled, Elastic Load Balancing waits for in-flight requests to complete before deregistering the instances.

  • Removed - All Auto Scaling instances are deregistered from the target group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..name: state
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..abstract:
One of the following load balancer states:

  • Adding - The instances in the group are being registered with the load balancer.

  • Added - All instances in the group are registered with the load balancer.

  • InService - At least one instance in the group passed an ELB health check.

  • Removing - The instances in the group are being deregistered from the load balancer. If connection draining is enabled, Elastic Load Balancing waits for in-flight requests to complete before deregistering the instances.

  • Removed - All instances in the group are deregistered from the load balancer.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: Defines the action the Auto Scaling group should take when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs. The valid values are CONTINUE and ABANDON. The default value is ABANDON.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out.

If the lifecycle hook times out, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action that you specified in the DefaultResult parameter. You can prevent the lifecycle hook from timing out by calling RecordLifecycleActionHeartbeat.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: lifecycleTransition
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
The state of the EC2 instance to which you want to attach the lifecycle hook. The valid values are:

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATING

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: Additional information that you want to include any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: The ARN of the target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends notifications to when an instance is in the transition state for the lifecycle hook. The notification target can be either an SQS queue or an SNS topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract: The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target, for example, an Amazon SNS topic or an Amazon SQS queue.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group for the lifecycle hook.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: defaultResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: Defines the action the Auto Scaling group should take when the lifecycle hook timeout elapses or if an unexpected failure occurs. The possible values are CONTINUE and ABANDON.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: globalTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that an instance can remain in a Pending:Wait or Terminating:Wait state. The maximum is 172800 seconds (48 hours) or 100 times HeartbeatTimeout, whichever is smaller.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: heartbeatTimeout
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The maximum time, in seconds, that can elapse before the lifecycle hook times out. If the lifecycle hook times out, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling performs the action that you specified in the DefaultResult parameter.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: lifecycleTransition
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract:
The state of the EC2 instance to which to attach the lifecycle hook. The following are possible values:

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_LAUNCHING

  • autoscaling:EC2_INSTANCE_TERMINATING

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: notificationMetadata
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: Additional information that is included any time Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends a message to the notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: notificationTargetARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The ARN of the target that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends notifications to when an instance is in the transition state for the lifecycle hook. The notification target can be either an SQS queue or an SNS topic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: roleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: The ARN of the IAM role that allows the Auto Scaling group to publish to the specified notification target.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: launchTemplateId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
The ID of the launch template. To get the template ID, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplates API operation. New launch templates can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplate API.

You must specify either a template ID or a template name.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: launchTemplateName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
The name of the launch template. To get the template name, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplates API operation. New launch templates can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplate API.

You must specify either a template ID or a template name.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: version
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
The version number, $Latest, or $Default. To get the version number, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeLaunchTemplateVersions API operation. New launch template versions can be created using the Amazon EC2 CreateLaunchTemplateVersion API.

If the value is $Latest, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects the latest version of the launch template when launching instances. If the value is $Default, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling selects the default version of the launch template when launching instances. The default value is $Default.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
The instance type. You must use an instance type that is supported in your requested Region and Availability Zones.

For information about available instance types, see Available Instance Types in the Amazon Elastic Compute Cloud User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: weightedCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
The number of capacity units, which gives the instance type a proportional weight to other instance types. For example, larger instance types are generally weighted more than smaller instance types. These are the same units that you chose to set the desired capacity in terms of instances, or a performance attribute such as vCPUs, memory, or I/O.

For more information, see Instance Weighting for Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 1. Maximum value of 999.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.name: launchTemplateSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.abstract: The launch template to use. You must specify either the launch template ID or launch template name in the request.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.name: overrides
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.abstract:
Any parameters that you specify override the same parameters in the launch template. Currently, the only supported override is instance type. You can specify between 1 and 20 instance types.

If not provided, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will use the instance type specified in the launch template to launch instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurations
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The launch configurations.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The launch configuration names. If you omit this parameter, all launch configurations are described.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: maxRecords
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The default value is 50 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The token for the next set of items to return. (You received this token from a previous call.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The name of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: associatePublicIpAddress
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
For Auto Scaling groups that are running in a VPC, specifies whether to assign a public IP address to the group’s instances.

For more information, see Launching Auto Scaling Instances in a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: blockDeviceMappings
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
A block device mapping, which specifies the block devices for the instance.

For more information, see Block Device Mapping in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: classicLinkVPCId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The ID of a ClassicLink-enabled VPC to link your EC2-Classic instances to.

For more information, see ClassicLink in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances and Linking EC2-Classic Instances to a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: classicLinkVPCSecurityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The IDs of one or more security groups for the VPC specified in ClassicLinkVPCId.

For more information, see ClassicLink in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances and Linking EC2-Classic Instances to a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: createdTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The creation date and time for the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: ebsOptimized
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
Specifies whether the launch configuration is optimized for EBS I/O (true) or not (false).

For more information, see Amazon EBS-Optimized Instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: iamInstanceProfile
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The name or the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile associated with the IAM role for the instance. The instance profile contains the IAM role.

For more information, see IAM Role for Applications That Run on Amazon EC2 Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: imageId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) to use to launch your EC2 instances.

For more information, see Finding an AMI in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: instanceMonitoring
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
Controls whether instances in this group are launched with detailed (true) or basic (false) monitoring.

For more information, see Configure Monitoring for Auto Scaling Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The instance type for the instances.

For information about available instance types, see Available Instance Types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: kernelId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The ID of the kernel associated with the AMI.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: keyName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The name of the key pair.

For more information, see Amazon EC2 Key Pairs in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The name of the launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: placementTenancy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The tenancy of the instance, either default or dedicated. An instance with dedicated tenancy runs on isolated, single-tenant hardware and can only be launched into a VPC.

For more information, see Instance Placement Tenancy in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: ramdiskId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: The ID of the RAM disk associated with the AMI.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: securityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
A list that contains the security groups to assign to the instances in the Auto Scaling group.

For more information, see Security Groups for Your VPC in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: spotPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The maximum hourly price to be paid for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request. Spot Instances are launched when the price you specify exceeds the current Spot price.

For more information, see Launching Spot Instances in Your Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: userData
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract:
The Base64-encoded user data to make available to the launched EC2 instances.

For more information, see Instance Metadata and User Data in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandAllocationStrategy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
Indicates how to allocate instance types to fulfill On-Demand capacity.

The only valid value is prioritized, which is also the default value. This strategy uses the order of instance type overrides for the LaunchTemplate to define the launch priority of each instance type. The first instance type in the array is prioritized higher than the last. If all your On-Demand capacity cannot be fulfilled using your highest priority instance, then the Auto Scaling groups launches the remaining capacity using the second priority instance type, and so on.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandBaseCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The minimum amount of the Auto Scaling group’s capacity that must be fulfilled by On-Demand Instances. This base portion is provisioned first as your group scales.

Default if not set is 0. If you leave it set to 0, On-Demand Instances are launched as a percentage of the Auto Scaling group’s desired capacity, per the OnDemandPercentageAboveBaseCapacity setting.

An update to this setting means a gradual replacement of instances to maintain the specified number of On-Demand Instances for your base capacity. When replacing instances, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches new instances before terminating the old ones.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: onDemandPercentageAboveBaseCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
Controls the percentages of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances for your additional capacity beyond OnDemandBaseCapacity.

Default if not set is 100. If you leave it set to 100, the percentages are 100% for On-Demand Instances and 0% for Spot Instances.

An update to this setting means a gradual replacement of instances to maintain the percentage of On-Demand Instances for your additional capacity above the base capacity. When replacing instances, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches new instances before terminating the old ones.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 0. Maximum value of 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotAllocationStrategy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
Indicates how to allocate instances across Spot Instance pools.

If the allocation strategy is lowest-price, the Auto Scaling group launches instances using the Spot pools with the lowest price, and evenly allocates your instances across the number of Spot pools that you specify. If the allocation strategy is capacity-optimized, the Auto Scaling group launches instances using Spot pools that are optimally chosen based on the available Spot capacity.

The default Spot allocation strategy for calls that you make through the API, the AWS CLI, or the AWS SDKs is lowest-price. The default Spot allocation strategy for the AWS Management Console is capacity-optimized.

Valid values: lowest-price | capacity-optimized

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotInstancePools
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The number of Spot Instance pools across which to allocate your Spot Instances. The Spot pools are determined from the different instance types in the Overrides array of LaunchTemplate. Default if not set is 2.

Used only when the Spot allocation strategy is lowest-price.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 1. Maximum value of 20.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: spotMaxPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
The maximum price per unit hour that you are willing to pay for a Spot Instance. If you leave the value of this parameter blank (which is the default), the maximum Spot price is set at the On-Demand price.

To remove a value that you previously set, include the parameter but leave the value blank.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: endTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The date and time at which the instance refresh ended.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: instancesToUpdate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The number of instances remaining to update before the instance refresh is complete.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: percentageComplete
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The percentage of the instance refresh that is complete. For each instance replacement, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling tracks the instance’s health status and warm-up time. When the instance’s health status changes to healthy and the specified warm-up time passes, the instance is considered updated and added to the percentage complete.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: startTime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: The date and time at which the instance refresh began.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: status
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract:
The current status for the instance refresh operation:

  • Pending - The request was created, but the operation has not started.

  • InProgress - The operation is in progress.

  • Successful - The operation completed successfully.

  • Failed - The operation failed to complete. You can troubleshoot using the status reason and the scaling activities.

  • Cancelling - An ongoing operation is being cancelled. Cancellation does not roll back any replacements that have already been completed, but it prevents new replacements from being started.

  • Cancelled - The operation is cancelled.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: statusReason
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: Provides more details about the current status of the instance refresh.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMonitoring.name: enabled
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMonitoring.abstract: If true, detailed monitoring is enabled. Otherwise, basic monitoring is enabled.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: availabilityZone
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: The Availability Zone in which the instance is running.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: healthStatus
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: The last reported health status of the instance. “Healthy” means that the instance is healthy and should remain in service. “Unhealthy” means that the instance is unhealthy and that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling should terminate and replace it.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: The instance type of the EC2 instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: The launch configuration associated with the instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: lifecycleState
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: A description of the current lifecycle state. The Quarantined state is not used.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: protectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract: Indicates whether the instance is protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.name: weightedCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstance.html#/c:o.abstract:
The number of capacity units contributed by the instance based on its instance type.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 1. Maximum value of 999.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.name: name
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.abstract: The name of the filter. The valid values are: auto-scaling-group, key, value, and propagate-at-launch.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.name: values
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html#/c:obj.abstract: One or more filter values. Filter values are case-sensitive.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFailedScheduledUpd.name: errorMessage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFailedScheduledUpd.abstract: The error message accompanying the error code.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyQuery.h.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyQuery.h.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyQuery.h.name: instanceIds
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyQuery.h.abstract: The IDs of the instances. You can specify up to 20 instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyAnswer..name: activities
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExitStandbyAnswer..abstract: The activities related to moving instances out of Standby mode.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..name: breachThreshold
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..abstract:
The breach threshold for the alarm.

Conditional: This parameter is required if the policy type is StepScaling and not supported otherwise.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..name: honorCooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..abstract:
Indicates whether Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits for the cooldown period to complete before executing the policy.

This parameter is not supported if the policy type is StepScaling or TargetTrackingScaling.

For more information, see Scaling Cooldowns in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..name: metricValue
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..abstract:
The metric value to compare to BreachThreshold. This enables you to execute a policy of type StepScaling and determine which step adjustment to use. For example, if the breach threshold is 50 and you want to use a step adjustment with a lower bound of 0 and an upper bound of 10, you can set the metric value to 59.

If you specify a metric value that doesn’t correspond to a step adjustment for the policy, the call returns an error.

Conditional: This parameter is required if the policy type is StepScaling and not supported otherwise.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..name: policyName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingExecutePolicyType..abstract: The name or ARN of the policy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..name: instanceIds
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..abstract: The IDs of the instances. You can specify up to 20 instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..name: shouldDecrementDesiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyQuery..abstract: Indicates whether to decrement the desired capacity of the Auto Scaling group by the number of instances moved to Standby mode.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyAnswer.name: activities
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnterStandbyAnswer.abstract: The activities related to moving instances into Standby mode.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnabledMetric.html.name: granularity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnabledMetric.html.abstract: The granularity of the metric. The only valid value is 1Minute.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.name: granularity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.abstract: The granularity to associate with the metrics to collect. The only valid value is 1Minute.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.name: metrics
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEnableMetricsColle.abstract:
Specifies which group-level metrics to start collecting. You can specify one or more of the following metrics:

  • GroupMinSize

  • GroupMaxSize

  • GroupDesiredCapacity

  • GroupInServiceInstances

  • GroupPendingInstances

  • GroupStandbyInstances

  • GroupTerminatingInstances

  • GroupTotalInstances

The instance weighting feature supports the following additional metrics:

  • GroupInServiceCapacity

  • GroupPendingCapacity

  • GroupStandbyCapacity

  • GroupTerminatingCapacity

  • GroupTotalCapacity

If you omit this parameter, all metrics are enabled.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: deleteOnTermination
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract: Indicates whether the volume is deleted on instance termination. For Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling, the default value is true.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: encrypted
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
Specifies whether the volume should be encrypted. Encrypted EBS volumes can only be attached to instances that support Amazon EBS encryption. For more information, see Supported Instance Types. If your AMI uses encrypted volumes, you can also only launch it on supported instance types.

If you are creating a volume from a snapshot, you cannot specify an encryption value. Volumes that are created from encrypted snapshots are automatically encrypted, and volumes that are created from unencrypted snapshots are automatically unencrypted. By default, encrypted snapshots use the AWS managed CMK that is used for EBS encryption, but you can specify a custom CMK when you create the snapshot. The ability to encrypt a snapshot during copying also allows you to apply a new CMK to an already-encrypted snapshot. Volumes restored from the resulting copy are only accessible using the new CMK.

Enabling encryption by default results in all EBS volumes being encrypted with the AWS managed CMK or a customer managed CMK, whether or not the snapshot was encrypted.

For more information, see Using Encryption with EBS-Backed AMIs in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances and Required CMK Key Policy for Use with Encrypted Volumes in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: iops
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The number of I/O operations per second (IOPS) to provision for the volume. The maximum ratio of IOPS to volume size (in GiB) is 50:1. For more information, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Conditional: This parameter is required when the volume type is io1. (Not used with standard, gp2, st1, or sc1 volumes.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: snapshotId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The snapshot ID of the volume to use.

Conditional: This parameter is optional if you specify a volume size. If you specify both SnapshotId and VolumeSize, VolumeSize must be equal or greater than the size of the snapshot.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: volumeSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The volume size, in Gibibytes (GiB).

This can be a number from 1-1,024 for standard, 4-16,384 for io1, 1-16,384 for gp2, and 500-16,384 for st1 and sc1. If you specify a snapshot, the volume size must be equal to or larger than the snapshot size.

Default: If you create a volume from a snapshot and you don’t specify a volume size, the default is the snapshot size.

At least one of VolumeSize or SnapshotId is required.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.name: volumeType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html#/c:objc(c.abstract:
The volume type, which can be standard for Magnetic, io1 for Provisioned IOPS SSD, gp2 for General Purpose SSD, st1 for Throughput Optimized HDD, or sc1 for Cold HDD. For more information, see Amazon EBS Volume Types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Valid Values: standard | io1 | gp2 | st1 | sc1

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCustomizedMetricSp.name: dimensions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCustomizedMetricSp.abstract:
The dimensions of the metric.
