Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: associatePublicIpAddress
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
For Auto Scaling groups that are running in a virtual private cloud (VPC), specifies whether to assign a public IP address to the group’s instances. If you specify true, each instance in the Auto Scaling group receives a unique public IP address. For more information, see Launching Auto Scaling Instances in a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

If you specify this parameter, you must specify at least one subnet for VPCZoneIdentifier when you create your group.

If the instance is launched into a default subnet, the default is to assign a public IP address, unless you disabled the option to assign a public IP address on the subnet. If the instance is launched into a nondefault subnet, the default is not to assign a public IP address, unless you enabled the option to assign a public IP address on the subnet.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: blockDeviceMappings
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: A block device mapping, which specifies the block devices for the instance. You can specify virtual devices and EBS volumes. For more information, see Block Device Mapping in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: classicLinkVPCId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The ID of a ClassicLink-enabled VPC to link your EC2-Classic instances to. For more information, see ClassicLink in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances and Linking EC2-Classic Instances to a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

This parameter can only be used if you are launching EC2-Classic instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: classicLinkVPCSecurityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The IDs of one or more security groups for the specified ClassicLink-enabled VPC. For more information, see ClassicLink in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances and Linking EC2-Classic Instances to a VPC in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

If you specify the ClassicLinkVPCId parameter, you must specify this parameter.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: ebsOptimized
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
Specifies whether the launch configuration is optimized for EBS I/O (true) or not (false). The optimization provides dedicated throughput to Amazon EBS and an optimized configuration stack to provide optimal I/O performance. This optimization is not available with all instance types. Additional fees are incurred when you enable EBS optimization for an instance type that is not EBS-optimized by default. For more information, see Amazon EBS-Optimized Instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

The default value is false.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: iamInstanceProfile
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The name or the Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the instance profile associated with the IAM role for the instance. The instance profile contains the IAM role.

For more information, see IAM Role for Applications That Run on Amazon EC2 Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: imageId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The ID of the Amazon Machine Image (AMI) that was assigned during registration. For more information, see Finding an AMI in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

If you do not specify InstanceId, you must specify ImageId.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: instanceId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The ID of the instance to use to create the launch configuration. The new launch configuration derives attributes from the instance, except for the block device mapping.

To create a launch configuration with a block device mapping or override any other instance attributes, specify them as part of the same request.

For more information, see Create a Launch Configuration Using an EC2 Instance in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

If you do not specify InstanceId, you must specify both ImageId and InstanceType.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: instanceMonitoring
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
Controls whether instances in this group are launched with detailed (true) or basic (false) monitoring.

The default value is true (enabled).

When detailed monitoring is enabled, Amazon CloudWatch generates metrics every minute and your account is charged a fee. When you disable detailed monitoring, CloudWatch generates metrics every 5 minutes. For more information, see Configure Monitoring for Auto Scaling Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
Specifies the instance type of the EC2 instance.

For information about available instance types, see Available Instance Types in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

If you do not specify InstanceId, you must specify InstanceType.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: kernelId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: The ID of the kernel associated with the AMI.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: keyName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: The name of the key pair. For more information, see Amazon EC2 Key Pairs in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: The name of the launch configuration. This name must be unique per Region per account.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: placementTenancy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The tenancy of the instance. An instance with dedicated tenancy runs on isolated, single-tenant hardware and can only be launched into a VPC.

To launch dedicated instances into a shared tenancy VPC (a VPC with the instance placement tenancy attribute set to default), you must set the value of this parameter to dedicated.

If you specify PlacementTenancy, you must specify at least one subnet for VPCZoneIdentifier when you create your group.

For more information, see Instance Placement Tenancy in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Valid Values: default | dedicated

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: ramdiskId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: The ID of the RAM disk to select.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: securityGroups
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
A list that contains the security groups to assign to the instances in the Auto Scaling group.

[EC2-VPC] Specify the security group IDs. For more information, see Security Groups for Your VPC in the Amazon Virtual Private Cloud User Guide.

[EC2-Classic] Specify either the security group names or the security group IDs. For more information, see Amazon EC2 Security Groups in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: spotPrice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract:
The maximum hourly price to be paid for any Spot Instance launched to fulfill the request. Spot Instances are launched when the price you specify exceeds the current Spot price. For more information, see Launching Spot Instances in Your Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

When you change your maximum price by creating a new launch configuration, running instances will continue to run as long as the maximum price for those running instances is higher than the current Spot price.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.name: userData
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateLaunchConfig.abstract: The Base64-encoded user data to make available to the launched EC2 instances. For more information, see Instance Metadata and User Data in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group. This name must be unique per Region per account.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: availabilityZones
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
One or more Availability Zones for the group. This parameter is optional if you specify one or more subnets for VPCZoneIdentifier.

Conditional: If your account supports EC2-Classic and VPC, this parameter is required to launch instances into EC2-Classic.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: defaultCooldown
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, after a scaling activity completes before another scaling activity can start. The default value is 300.

For more information, see Scaling Cooldowns in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The desired capacity is the initial capacity of the Auto Scaling group at the time of its creation and the capacity it attempts to maintain. It can scale beyond this capacity if you configure automatic scaling.

This number must be greater than or equal to the minimum size of the group and less than or equal to the maximum size of the group. If you do not specify a desired capacity, the default is the minimum size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: healthCheckGracePeriod
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The amount of time, in seconds, that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits before checking the health status of an EC2 instance that has come into service. During this time, any health check failures for the instance are ignored. The default value is 0.

For more information, see Health Check Grace Period in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Conditional: This parameter is required if you are adding an ELB health check.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: healthCheckType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The service to use for the health checks. The valid values are EC2 and ELB. The default value is EC2. If you configure an Auto Scaling group to use ELB health checks, it considers the instance unhealthy if it fails either the EC2 status checks or the load balancer health checks.

For more information, see Health Checks for Auto Scaling Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: instanceId
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The ID of the instance used to create a launch configuration for the group. To get the instance ID, use the Amazon EC2 DescribeInstances API operation.

When you specify an ID of an instance, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling creates a new launch configuration and associates it with the group. This launch configuration derives its attributes from the specified instance, except for the block device mapping.

You must specify one of the following parameters in your request: LaunchConfigurationName, LaunchTemplate, InstanceId, or MixedInstancesPolicy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The name of the launch configuration to use when an instance is launched. To get the launch configuration name, use the DescribeLaunchConfigurations API operation. New launch configurations can be created with the CreateLaunchConfiguration API.

You must specify one of the following parameters in your request: LaunchConfigurationName, LaunchTemplate, InstanceId, or MixedInstancesPolicy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: launchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
Parameters used to specify the launch template and version to use when an instance is launched.

For more information, see LaunchTemplateSpecification in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference.

You can alternatively associate a launch template to the Auto Scaling group by using the MixedInstancesPolicy parameter.

You must specify one of the following parameters in your request: LaunchConfigurationName, LaunchTemplate, InstanceId, or MixedInstancesPolicy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: lifecycleHookSpecificationList
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract: One or more lifecycle hooks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: loadBalancerNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
A list of Classic Load Balancers associated with this Auto Scaling group. For Application Load Balancers and Network Load Balancers, specify a list of target groups using the TargetGroupARNs property instead.

For more information, see Using a Load Balancer with an Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: maxInstanceLifetime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The maximum amount of time, in seconds, that an instance can be in service. The default is null.

This parameter is optional, but if you specify a value for it, you must specify a value of at least 604,800 seconds (7 days). To clear a previously set value, specify a new value of 0.

For more information, see Replacing Auto Scaling Instances Based on Maximum Instance Lifetime in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 0.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The maximum size of the group.

With a mixed instances policy that uses instance weighting, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling may need to go above MaxSize to meet your capacity requirements. In this event, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling will never go above MaxSize by more than your maximum instance weight (weights that define how many capacity units each instance contributes to the capacity of the group).

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract: The minimum size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: mixedInstancesPolicy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
An embedded object that specifies a mixed instances policy. The required parameters must be specified. If optional parameters are unspecified, their default values are used.

The policy includes parameters that not only define the distribution of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances, the maximum price to pay for Spot Instances, and how the Auto Scaling group allocates instance types to fulfill On-Demand and Spot capacity, but also the parameters that specify the instance configuration informationthe launch template and instance types.

For more information, see MixedInstancesPolicy in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling API Reference and Auto Scaling Groups with Multiple Instance Types and Purchase Options in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

You must specify one of the following parameters in your request: LaunchConfigurationName, LaunchTemplate, InstanceId, or MixedInstancesPolicy.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: latestInstancesProtectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
Indicates whether newly launched instances are protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

For more information about preventing instances from terminating on scale in, see Instance Protection in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: placementGroup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract: The name of the placement group into which to launch your instances, if any. A placement group is a logical grouping of instances within a single Availability Zone. You cannot specify multiple Availability Zones and a placement group. For more information, see Placement Groups in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: serviceLinkedRoleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service-linked role that the Auto Scaling group uses to call other AWS services on your behalf. By default, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling uses a service-linked role named AWSServiceRoleForAutoScaling, which it creates if it does not exist. For more information, see Service-Linked Roles in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: tags
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
One or more tags. You can tag your Auto Scaling group and propagate the tags to the Amazon EC2 instances it launches.

Tags are not propagated to Amazon EBS volumes. To add tags to Amazon EBS volumes, specify the tags in a launch template but use caution. If the launch template specifies an instance tag with a key that is also specified for the Auto Scaling group, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling overrides the value of that instance tag with the value specified by the Auto Scaling group.

For more information, see Tagging Auto Scaling Groups and Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: targetGroupARNs
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the target groups to associate with the Auto Scaling group. Instances are registered as targets in a target group, and traffic is routed to the target group.

For more information, see Using a Load Balancer with an Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: terminationPolicies
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
One or more termination policies used to select the instance to terminate. These policies are executed in the order that they are listed.

For more information, see Controlling Which Instances Auto Scaling Terminates During Scale In in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.name: VPCZoneIdentifier
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCreateAutoScalingG.abstract:
A comma-separated list of subnet IDs for your virtual private cloud (VPC).

If you specify VPCZoneIdentifier with AvailabilityZones, the subnets that you specify for this parameter must reside in those Availability Zones.

Conditional: If your account supports EC2-Classic and VPC, this parameter is required to launch instances into a VPC.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.name: lifecycleActionResult
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.abstract: The action for the group to take. This parameter can be either CONTINUE or ABANDON.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.name: lifecycleActionToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCompleteLifecycleA.abstract: A universally unique identifier (UUID) that identifies a specific lifecycle action associated with an instance. Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling sends this token to the notification target you specified when you created the lifecycle hook.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCancelInstanceRefr.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCancelInstanceRefr.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.name: deviceName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.abstract: The device name exposed to the EC2 instance (for example, /dev/sdh or xvdh). For more information, see Device Naming on Linux Instances in the Amazon EC2 User Guide for Linux Instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.name: ebs
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.abstract:
Parameters used to automatically set up EBS volumes when an instance is launched.

You can specify either VirtualName or Ebs, but not both.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.name: noDevice
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.abstract:
Setting this value to true suppresses the specified device included in the block device mapping of the AMI.

If NoDevice is true for the root device, instances might fail the EC2 health check. In that case, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches replacement instances.

If you specify NoDevice, you cannot specify Ebs.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.name: virtualName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBlockDeviceMapping.abstract:
The name of the virtual device (for example, ephemeral0).

You can specify either VirtualName or Ebs, but not both.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.name: scheduledUpdateGroupActions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.abstract: One or more scheduled actions. The maximum number allowed is 50.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.name: failedScheduledUpdateGroupActions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchPutScheduledU.abstract: The names of the scheduled actions that could not be created or updated, including an error message.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.name: scheduledActionNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.abstract: The names of the scheduled actions to delete. The maximum number allowed is 50.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.name: failedScheduledActions
Classes/AWSAutoScalingBatchDeleteSchedul.abstract: The names of the scheduled actions that could not be deleted, including an error message.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group for the instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: healthStatus
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: The last reported health status of this instance. “Healthy” means that the instance is healthy and should remain in service. “Unhealthy” means that the instance is unhealthy and Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling should terminate and replace it.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: instanceType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: The instance type of the EC2 instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: launchConfigurationName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: The launch configuration used to launch the instance. This value is not available if you attached the instance to the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: protectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: Indicates whether the instance is protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: weightedCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract:
The number of capacity units contributed by the instance based on its instance type.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 1. Maximum value of 999.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupsT.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupsT.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.name: autoScalingGroupNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.abstract:
The names of the Auto Scaling groups. Each name can be a maximum of 1600 characters. By default, you can only specify up to 50 names. You can optionally increase this limit using the MaxRecords parameter.

If you omit this parameter, all Auto Scaling groups are described.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.name: maxRecords
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.abstract: The maximum number of items to return with this call. The default value is 50 and the maximum value is 100.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroupNa.abstract: The token for the next set of items to return. (You received this token from a previous call.)

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: autoScalingGroupARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: availabilityZones
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: One or more Availability Zones for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: createdTime

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: defaultCooldown

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: desiredCapacity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The desired size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: enabledMetrics
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The metrics enabled for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: healthCheckGracePeriod
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The amount of time, in seconds, that Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling waits before checking the health status of an EC2 instance that has come into service.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: healthCheckType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The service to use for the health checks. The valid values are EC2 and ELB. If you configure an Auto Scaling group to use ELB health checks, it considers the instance unhealthy if it fails either the EC2 status checks or the load balancer health checks.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: instances
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The EC2 instances associated with the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: launchConfigurationName

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: launchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The launch template for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: loadBalancerNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: One or more load balancers associated with the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: maxInstanceLifetime
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract:
The maximum amount of time, in seconds, that an instance can be in service.

Valid Range: Minimum value of 0.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: maxSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The maximum size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: minSize
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The minimum size of the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: mixedInstancesPolicy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The mixed instances policy for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: latestInstancesProtectedFromScaleIn
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: Indicates whether newly launched instances are protected from termination by Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling when scaling in.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: placementGroup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The name of the placement group into which to launch your instances, if any.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: serviceLinkedRoleARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the service-linked role that the Auto Scaling group uses to call other AWS services on your behalf.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: status
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The current state of the group when the DeleteAutoScalingGroup operation is in progress.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: suspendedProcesses
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The suspended processes associated with the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: tags
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The tags for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: targetGroupARNs
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the target groups for your load balancer.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: terminationPolicies
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: The termination policies for the group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: VPCZoneIdentifier
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: One or more subnet IDs, if applicable, separated by commas.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.name: loadBalancerNames
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.abstract: The names of the load balancers. You can specify up to 10 load balancers.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.name: targetGroupARNs
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachLoadBalancer.abstract: The Amazon Resource Names (ARN) of the target groups. You can specify up to 10 target groups.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachInstancesQue.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachInstancesQue.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachInstancesQue.name: instanceIds
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAttachInstancesQue.abstract: The IDs of the instances. You can specify up to 20 instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAlarm.html#/c:objc.name: alarmARN
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAlarm.html#/c:objc.abstract: The Amazon Resource Name (ARN) of the alarm.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAdjustmentType.htm.name: adjustmentType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAdjustmentType.htm.abstract: The policy adjustment type. The valid values are ChangeInCapacity, ExactCapacity, and PercentChangeInCapacity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.name: autoScalingGroupName
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.abstract: The name of the Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.name: detail
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.abstract: A friendly, more verbose description of the activity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.name: progress
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.abstract: A value between 0 and 100 that indicates the progress of the activity.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.name: statusMessage
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html#/c:o.abstract: A friendly, more verbose description of the activity status.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivitiesType.htm.name: activities
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivitiesType.htm.abstract: The scaling activities. Activities are sorted by start time. Activities still in progress are described first.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivitiesType.htm.name: nextToken
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivitiesType.htm.abstract: A string that indicates that the response contains more items than can be returned in a single response. To receive additional items, specify this string for the NextToken value when requesting the next set of items. This value is null when there are no more items to return.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html.name: AWSAutoScalingActivity
Classes/AWSAutoScalingActivity.html.abstract: Describes scaling activity, which is a long-running process that represents a change to your Auto Scaling group, such as changing its size or replacing an instance.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.name: AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingGroup.h.abstract: Describes an Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.name: AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanceDetails
Classes/AWSAutoScalingAutoScalingInstanc.abstract: Describes an EC2 instance associated with an Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingCustomizedMetricSp.name: AWSAutoScalingCustomizedMetricSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingCustomizedMetricSp.abstract:
Represents a CloudWatch metric of your choosing for a target tracking scaling policy to use with Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling.

To create your customized metric specification:

  • Add values for each required parameter from CloudWatch. You can use an existing metric, or a new metric that you create. To use your own metric, you must first publish the metric to CloudWatch. For more information, see Publish Custom Metrics in the Amazon CloudWatch User Guide.

  • Choose a metric that changes proportionally with capacity. The value of the metric should increase or decrease in inverse proportion to the number of capacity units. That is, the value of the metric should decrease when capacity increases.

For more information about CloudWatch, see Amazon CloudWatch Concepts.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html.name: AWSAutoScalingEbs
Classes/AWSAutoScalingEbs.html.abstract: Describes information used to set up an Amazon EBS volume specified in a block device mapping.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFailedScheduledUpd.name: AWSAutoScalingFailedScheduledUpdateGroupActionRequest
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFailedScheduledUpd.abstract: Describes a scheduled action that could not be created, updated, or deleted.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html.name: AWSAutoScalingFilter
Classes/AWSAutoScalingFilter.html.abstract:
Describes a filter that is used to return a more specific list of results when describing tags.

For more information, see Tagging Auto Scaling Groups and Instances in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMonitoring.name: AWSAutoScalingInstanceMonitoring
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceMonitoring.abstract: Describes whether detailed monitoring is enabled for the Auto Scaling instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.name: AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstanceRefresh.ht.abstract: Describes an instance refresh for an Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.name: AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribution
Classes/AWSAutoScalingInstancesDistribut.abstract:
Describes an instances distribution for an Auto Scaling group with a MixedInstancesPolicy.

The instances distribution specifies the distribution of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances, the maximum price to pay for Spot Instances, and how the Auto Scaling group allocates instance types to fulfill On-Demand and Spot capacity.

When you update SpotAllocationStrategy, SpotInstancePools, or SpotMaxPrice, this update action does not deploy any changes across the running Amazon EC2 instances in the group. Your existing Spot Instances continue to run as long as the maximum price for those instances is higher than the current Spot price. When scale out occurs, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches instances based on the new settings. When scale in occurs, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling terminates instances according to the group’s termination policies.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.name: AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchConfiguratio.abstract: Describes a launch configuration.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.name: AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplate.htm.abstract:
Describes a launch template and overrides.

The overrides are used to override the instance type specified by the launch template with multiple instance types that can be used to launch On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances.

When you update the launch template or overrides, existing Amazon EC2 instances continue to run. When scale out occurs, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches instances to match the new settings. When scale in occurs, Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling terminates instances according to the group’s termination policies.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.name: AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOverrides
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateOver.abstract:
Describes an override for a launch template. Currently, the only supported override is instance type.

The maximum number of instance type overrides that can be associated with an Auto Scaling group is 20.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.name: AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLaunchTemplateSpec.abstract:
Describes the Amazon EC2 launch template and the launch template version that can be used by an Auto Scaling group to configure Amazon EC2 instances.

The launch template that is specified must be configured for use with an Auto Scaling group. For more information, see Creating a Launch Template for an Auto Scaling Group in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.name: AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHook.html.abstract: Describes a lifecycle hook, which tells Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling that you want to perform an action whenever it launches instances or terminates instances.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.name: AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLifecycleHookSpeci.abstract:
Describes information used to specify a lifecycle hook for an Auto Scaling group.

A lifecycle hook tells Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling to perform an action on an instance when the instance launches (before it is put into service) or as the instance terminates (before it is fully terminated).

This step is a part of the procedure for creating a lifecycle hook for an Auto Scaling group:

  1. (Optional) Create a Lambda function and a rule that allows CloudWatch Events to invoke your Lambda function when Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling launches or terminates instances.

  2. (Optional) Create a notification target and an IAM role. The target can be either an Amazon SQS queue or an Amazon SNS topic. The role allows Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling to publish lifecycle notifications to the target.

  3. Create the lifecycle hook. Specify whether the hook is used when the instances launch or terminate.

  4. If you need more time, record the lifecycle action heartbeat to keep the instance in a pending state.

  5. If you finish before the timeout period ends, complete the lifecycle action.

For more information, see Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling Lifecycle Hooks in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..name: AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerState..abstract:
Describes the state of a Classic Load Balancer.

If you specify a load balancer when creating the Auto Scaling group, the state of the load balancer is InService.

If you attach a load balancer to an existing Auto Scaling group, the initial state is Adding. The state transitions to Added after all instances in the group are registered with the load balancer. If Elastic Load Balancing health checks are enabled for the load balancer, the state transitions to InService after at least one instance in the group passes the health check. If EC2 health checks are enabled instead, the load balancer remains in the Added state.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.name: AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTargetGroupState
Classes/AWSAutoScalingLoadBalancerTarget.abstract:
Describes the state of a target group.

If you attach a target group to an existing Auto Scaling group, the initial state is Adding. The state transitions to Added after all Auto Scaling instances are registered with the target group. If Elastic Load Balancing health checks are enabled, the state transitions to InService after at least one Auto Scaling instance passes the health check. If EC2 health checks are enabled instead, the target group remains in the Added state.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.name: AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPolicy
Classes/AWSAutoScalingMixedInstancesPoli.abstract:
Describes a mixed instances policy for an Auto Scaling group. With mixed instances, your Auto Scaling group can provision a combination of On-Demand Instances and Spot Instances across multiple instance types. For more information, see Auto Scaling Groups with Multiple Instance Types and Purchase Options in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

You can create a mixed instances policy for a new Auto Scaling group, or you can create it for an existing group by updating the group to specify MixedInstancesPolicy as the top-level parameter instead of a launch configuration or template. For more information, see CreateAutoScalingGroup and UpdateAutoScalingGroup.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.name: AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSpecification
Classes/AWSAutoScalingPredefinedMetricSp.abstract: Represents a predefined metric for a target tracking scaling policy to use with Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingProcessType.html.name: AWSAutoScalingProcessType
Classes/AWSAutoScalingProcessType.html.abstract:
Describes a process type.

For more information, see Scaling Processes in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.name: AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences
Classes/AWSAutoScalingRefreshPreferences.abstract: Describes information used to start an instance refresh.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.name: AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGroupActionRequest
Classes/AWSAutoScalingScheduledUpdateGro.abstract:
Describes information used for one or more scheduled scaling action updates in a BatchPutScheduledUpdateGroupAction operation.

When updating a scheduled scaling action, all optional parameters are left unchanged if not specified.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.name: AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment
Classes/AWSAutoScalingStepAdjustment.htm.abstract:
Describes information used to create a step adjustment for a step scaling policy.

For the following examples, suppose that you have an alarm with a breach threshold of 50:

  • To trigger the adjustment when the metric is greater than or equal to 50 and less than 60, specify a lower bound of 0 and an upper bound of 10.

  • To trigger the adjustment when the metric is greater than 40 and less than or equal to 50, specify a lower bound of -10 and an upper bound of 0.

There are a few rules for the step adjustments for your step policy:

  • The ranges of your step adjustments can’t overlap or have a gap.

  • At most, one step adjustment can have a null lower bound. If one step adjustment has a negative lower bound, then there must be a step adjustment with a null lower bound.

  • At most, one step adjustment can have a null upper bound. If one step adjustment has a positive upper bound, then there must be a step adjustment with a null upper bound.

  • The upper and lower bound can’t be null in the same step adjustment.

For more information, see Step Adjustments in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingSuspendedProcess.h.name: AWSAutoScalingSuspendedProcess
Classes/AWSAutoScalingSuspendedProcess.h.abstract:
Describes an automatic scaling process that has been suspended.

For more information, see Scaling Processes in the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html.name: AWSAutoScalingTag
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTag.html.abstract: Describes a tag for an Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.name: AWSAutoScalingTagDescription
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTagDescription.htm.abstract: Describes a tag for an Auto Scaling group.

Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.name: AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConfiguration
Classes/AWSAutoScalingTargetTrackingConf.abstract: Represents a target tracking scaling policy configuration to use with Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling.

Classes/AWSAutoScaling.html.name: AWSAutoScaling
Classes/AWSAutoScaling.html.abstract:
Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling

Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling is designed to automatically launch or terminate EC2 instances based on user-defined scaling policies, scheduled actions, and health checks. Use this service with AWS Auto Scaling, Amazon CloudWatch, and Elastic Load Balancing.

For more information, including information about granting IAM users required permissions for Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling actions, see the Amazon EC2 Auto Scaling User Guide.
